metadata.title: Turner Syndrome  Speech Therapy
anatomical location body part affected: Sex organs; endocrine system; may also affect kidneys, heart, ears
description: Turner syndrome (TS) is a congenital genetic disorder resulting from the complete or partial deletion of the second sex chromosome, either X or Y .(1,2) Subsequently, all patients with TS will present clinically as female.(1) The pattern of symptoms associated with TS includes short stature, premature ovarian failure, loose nuchal skin (skin at the nape of the neck) or webbing at the neck and the absence of spontaneous puberty(1,2)

ICD-10 codes.Q96.2: karyotype 46,X with abnormal sex chromosome, except iso (Xq)
ICD-10 codes.Q96.4: mosaicism, 45,X/other cell line(s) with abnormal sex chromosome
ICD-10 codes.Q96.9: Turner's syndrome, unspecified (ICD codes are provided for the readers’ reference, not for billing purposes)

Swallowing G-code set.G8996: Swallowing functional limitation, current status at time of initial therapy treatment/episode outset and reporting intervals
Swallowing G-code set.G8997: Swallowing functional limitation, projected goal status, at initial therapy treatment/outset and at discharge from therapy
Swallowing G-code set.G8998: Swallowing functional limitation, discharge status, at discharge from therapy/ end of reporting on limitation

Spoken Language Comprehension G-code set.G9159: Spoken language comprehension functional limitation, current status at time of initial therapy treatment/episode outset and reporting intervals
Spoken Language Comprehension G-code set.G9160: Spoken language comprehension functional limitation, projected goal status at initial therapy treatment/outset and at discharge from therapy
Spoken Language Comprehension G-code set.G9161: Spoken language comprehension functional limitation, discharge status at discharge from therapy/end of reporting on limitation

Spoken Language Expressive G-code set.G9162: Spoken language expression functional limitation, current status at time of initial therapy treatment/episode outset and reporting intervals
Spoken Language Expressive G-code set.G9163: Spoken language expression functional limitation, projected goal status at initial therapy treatment/outset and at discharge from therapy
Spoken Language Expressive G-code set.G9164: Spoken language expression functional limitation, discharge status at discharge from therapy/end of reporting on limitation

Attention G-code set.G9165: Attention functional limitation, current status at time of initial therapy treatment/episode outset and reporting intervals
Attention G-code set.G9166: Attention functional limitation, projected goal status at initial therapy treatment/outset and at discharge from therapy
Attention G-code set.G9167: Attention functional limitation, discharge status at discharge from therapy/end of reporting on limitation

Memory G-code set.G9169: Memory functional limitation, projected goal status at initial therapy treatment/outset and at discharge from therapy
Memory G-code set.G9170: Memory functional limitation, discharge status at discharge from therapy/end of reporting on limitation

Voice G-code set.G9171: V oice functional limitation, current status at time of initial therapy treatment/episode outset and reporting intervals
Voice G-code set.G9172: V oice functional limitation, projected goal status at initial therapy treatment/outset and at discharge from therapy
Voice G-code set.G9173: V oice functional limitation, discharge status at discharge from therapy/end of reporting on limitation

Other Speech Language Pathology G-code s.G9174: Other speech language pathology functional limitation, current status at time of initial therapy treatment/episode outset and reporting intervals
Other Speech Language Pathology G-code s.G9175: Other speech language pathology functional limitation, projected goal status at initial therapy treatment/outset and at discharge from therapy
Other Speech Language Pathology G-code s.G9176: Other speech language pathology functional limitation, discharge status at discharge from therapy/end of reporting on limitation

reimbursement: Reimbursement for therapy will depend on insurance contract coverage; no specific issues or information have been identified regarding reimbursement
presentation signs and symptoms: Cardiovascular abnormalities (especially left-sided)(1,3,4,32) –Coarctation (narrowing of the aorta)(1)  –Aortic valvular disease(1,3) –Aortic dissection(1,3,32)
Cubitus valgus (increased carrying angle of the elbow)(1,2,3)
Delayed or absent menses (amenorrhea); lack of spontaneous puberty (hypogonadism)(2,3,4,5)
Edema in the hands and feet (in infants)(1,5)
Learning disabilities(2) –Impaired spatial perception; impaired spatial language abilities(2,36,37)
Kidney complications (pelvic kidney or horseshoe kidneys)(2,5)
Vision problems (strabismus, colorblindness)(3) Causes, Pathogenesis, & Risk Factors
contraindications precautions to test: Patients with TS are at an elevated risk for depression and emotional disorders due to their chronic medical problems, social isolation,and physical differences.(4,6) A speech-language  pathologist (SLP) must proceed with sensitivity during evaluations of speech, language, cognition, and swallowing and refer to psychiatry or psychology as needed

risk factors: Family history of chromosome translocations involving the X chromosome(1)
No association between TS and advanced maternal age(4)

overall contraindications precautions: See specific  Contraindications/precautions to examination   and  Contraindications/precautions   under Assessment/

history of present illness.mechanism of injury or etiology of illne: When was the patient diagnosed with TS? -Review history and physical from the patient’s pediatrician or primary care physicianFor pediatric patients -Was the child a quiet or vocal infant? -Did the child coo, babble, or imitate sounds as an infant? -At what age did these behaviors begin? -When did the child say his or her first word? -At what age did the child begin to name objects or people? -At what age did the child start to put words together (e.g., “Daddy up”)? -Were the child’s first words easy or difficult to understand? -Currently, what specific sounds does the child make? -Which sounds or words are hard to understand?For pediatric patients -Did the child’s mother have any illnesses, accidents, or complications while pregnant with the child? -Did the mother take any medications during the pregnancy? -What was the length of the pregnancy with the child? -What was the duration of the delivery? -What was the child’s weight at birth? -Were there any complications or unusual circumstances during birth or shortly after? -What were the Apgar scores?

course of treatment.medical management: Multiple specialists are typically involved in the medical management of patients with TS.(34) Specialists must communicate with each other to ensure medical treatments are not contraindicated or redundant(2) Surgery to remove gonads is recommended in TS patients with an X/XY mosaicism (a condition in which cells within the same individual have a different genetic makeup) to prevent complications(1)
course of treatment.medications: Determine what medications physician has prescribed; are they being taken? Androgen replacement therapy(8) A study conducted in the United States with a randomized, double-blind,  placebo-controlled design, noted significant improvements in working memory skills of patients with TS on androgen replacement therapy(7) Calcium supplement(4) Estrogen replacement therapy (ERT)(2,6,30) Can begin in early adolescence (ages 1214 years)(1,2,6) The goal of ERT is to initiate and normalize the pace of puberty(1,30) Other benefits of ERT appear to include improved bone mass, as well as optimization of cognitive and motor function(1,6) Recombinant growth hormone (GH) therapy(1,4,5,6) Typically initiated when the patient’s height is outside of2 standard deviations below the norm OR by 8 years of age;(1) however. The optimal age for GH treatment as well as its appropriate duration in patients with TS is debated among medical professionals and in medical literature.(27) Per Clinical Guidelines developed at the 2016 Cincinnati International Turner Syndrome Meeting and endorsed by the American Academy of Pediatrics, recommendation is the early initiation of GH, by ages 4  6 years, if the child exhibits a growth failure or is already considerably short for her age(36,37) Use of GH might increase the risk of otitis media and joint disorders(6) Can be given in combination with androgen replacement(5,6) Multiple studies have found that the combination of androgen replacement therapy and GH replacement therapy will lower the frequency of the voice in patients with TS  In a cross-sectional  study conducted in Sweden of 117 women with TS who were controlled for karyotype and age, researchers found that androgen and GH replacement therapies normalized a highpitched  voice in these patients(8) In a multicenter, randomized, placebo-controlled,  double-blind  study conducted in the Netherlands including girls with TS aged 812  years, researchers found that the addition of oxandrolone (a synthetic derivative of testosterone) to a treatment regimen of GH lowered the frequency of the voice in girls with TS into the normal range(9) The voice frequency was lowered in a dose-dependent  manner; hence, if the resulting vocal pitch was found to be abnormally low, the dose of oxandrolone was reduced(9)
diagnostic tests completed: Diagnostic tests completed:  Usual tests for this condition are the following:

Per Clinical Guidelines developed at the 2016 Cincinnati International Turner Syndrome Meeting and endorsed by the American Academy of Pediatrics, clinicians should consider the TS diagnosis in phenotypic females with a karyotype having one X chromosome and complete or partial absence of the second sex chromosome who display at least one clinical feature of TS. Additionally, genetic testing for TS should be performed in females who exhibit the typical signs of TS(36,37)
Diagnosis of TS is confirmed by molecular DNA testing(2)
Giemsa banding staining technique(2)
TS may be discovered during chorionic villus sampling (CVS) or amniocentesis which is performed for another reason (i.e., advanced maternal age)
Early diagnosis and medical intervention improves functional outcomes for girls with TS(3,4)
Cardiac evaluation: cardiac complications are common in patients with TS(1,2,34)
Blood pressure(1)
Echocardiogram(4)
Electrocardiogram (EKG/ECG)(1,2)
Endocrine evaluation(2,4)
Due to the lack of the second sex chromosome, patients with TS may have hormonal deficits(2)
Thyroid function testing(1)
Neurological evaluation
MRI/CT scan of the brain(2)
Neuropsychological evaluation(2)
To be completed by a qualified psychiatrist or neuropsychologist
Might include IQ testing (Stanford-Binet; Wechsler Intelligence Scale for Children: revised edition [WISC-R])
Tests for learning disabilities(2)
Girls with TS typically present with normal global intelligence
Verbal intelligence is generally strong in patients with TS(9)
Renal ultrasound(1,2)
course of treatment.alternative therapies: Document any use of home remedies (e.g., ice or heating pack) or alternative therapies (e.g., acupuncture) and whether they help or not
course of treatment.previous therapy: Document whether the patient has had speech, occupational or physical therapy for this or other conditions and what specific treatments were helpful or not helpful

history of present illness.aggravating easing factors: Aggravating/easing factors -Are there certain times of day that the patient’s speech is better or worse? -Does the patient speak more clearly with certain people or teachers? -Are there specific situations in which the patient’s speech is more or less understandable? -Highly social situations can increase social anxiety behaviors in TS patients(10)
history of present illness.other symptoms: Document other symptoms patient is experiencing which could exacerbate the condition and/or symptoms that could be indicative of a need to refer to the physician
history of present illness.respiratory status: Does the patient require supplemental oxygen? Nasal cannula? Does the patient have a tracheostomy tube? Does the patient require ventilator support?Document any history of psychosocial disturbance  -Patients with TS are at elevated risk for depression and emotional disorders due to their chronic medical problems, social isolation, and physical differences(4,6)Document hearing abilities, including presence and severity of hearing loss as well as the use of hearing aids -Prevalence of hearing loss in women with TS appears greater than in that of the general population(11,12,13) -In a study conducted in Brazil with 52 patients with TS, researchers found that those patients with a 45,X karyotype and isochromosomes with loss of the p-arm  of the X chromosome had a higher risk of developing hearing loss than patients with mosaicism(25) -Cholesteatoma (an abnormal skin growth within the middle ear) occurs with higher frequency in patients with TS compared to the general population. Cholesteatoma can cause conductive hearing loss and when left untreated can result in serious medical complications (e.g., brain abscess, meningitis)(29)Document history of ear infections in all patients with TS.(1) Children with chronic middle ear infections have increased risk for speech and language delays.(14)Per Clinical Guidelines developed at the 2016 Cincinnati International Turner Syndrome Meeting and endorsed by the American Academy of Pediatrics, ear infections should be treated aggressively in children with TS using antibiotics and placement of myringotomy tubes if necessary.(36,37) -How long did the ear infections last? -How frequently did the child have ear infections? -Does the child presently have an ear infection? Barriers to learning -Are there any barriers to learning? Yes__ No__ -If Yes, describe _________________________

past medical history.previous history of same similar diagnos: Family history of same/similar diagnosis Is there a family history of TS? Is there a family history of any genetic or congenital disorders?
past medical history.comorbid diagnoses: Ask patient or parent/caregiver about other problems including frequent otitis media, hearing impairment, diabetes, emotional disorders, depression, and orthopedic disorders Common comorbidities include frequent otitis media (ear infections),(1) hearing impairment,(11,12,13) cardiovascular anomalies,(1) ADHD,(4,6) renal abnormalities,(1,3,5) autoimmune diseases,(31) hypertension,(1,5) glucose intolerance,(1,3) hyperlipidemia,(1) and hypothyroidism(1,3) Although pregnancy is possible through in vitro technology (via egg donation) for a greater percentage of patients with TS, there is a high risk of maternal mortality due to cardiac complications(1,28) Pregnant TS patients must be monitored very closely throughout the pregnancy due to cardiac complication risk(1,28) Although extremely rare, spontaneous pregnancy (without egg donation) has been documented in patients with TS(26,28)
past medical history.medications previously prescribed: Obtain a comprehensive list of medications prescribed and/or being taken (including overthe-counter  drugs) Medications might have been prescribed for comorbid conditions such as cardiac issues, renal problems, thyroid deficiencies, or diabetes(3)
past medical history.other symptoms: Ask the patient or family/caregiver about other symptoms patient is experiencing

social and occupational history.vocation avocation and associated repeti: Vocation/avocation and associated repetitive behaviors, if any -What interests, hobbies, or other activities does the pediatric patient have? -What type of interests, hobbies, employment, or other activities does the adult patient have?
social and occupational history.functional limitations assistance with A: Functional limitations/assistance with ADLs/adaptive equipment -Does the patient use a walker, wheelchair, and leg braces? -Does the patient have a hearing loss? Does the patient require/wear hearing aids or have cochlear implants? -Does the patient require/wear glasses? -Does the patient use an assistive or augmentative communication device?
social and occupational history.living environment: With whom does the patient live (e.g., caregivers, family members)? -Identify if there are barriers to independence in the home and any modifications are necessary? -Is the patient exposed to any other languages at home or school? -What percentage of time is each language spoken around/to the patient?

relevant tests and measures.general: (While tests and measures are listed in alphabetical order, sequencing should be ›Relevant tests and measures: (While tests and measures are listed in alphabetical order, sequencing should be appropriate to patient medical condition, functional status, and setting)
relevant tests and measures.speech and language examination: Patients with TS sometimes have speech and/or language disorders. Speech and language deficits are common in girls with TS; however, the deficits are often subtle and therefore can remain undiagnosed.(22) A full speech/language evaluation to include standardized tests of speech and language may be performed at the discretion of an SLP –A survey (given to patients or their parents) of 128 Belgian females with TS ranging in age from 2.4 to 58.8 years revealed that 24% of the patients were receiving or had received speech/language treatment for at least one of the -Articulation disorders(15) -Delayed language development(15) -Stuttering(15)Assess speech production and intelligibility with formal and informal measures of articulation -For detailed information on assessment and treatment of children with articulation disorders, see Clinical Review…Articulation Disorders, Functional ; CINAHL Topic ID NumberArticulation Disorders, Organic ; CINAHL Topic ID Number  –Language -In a research study conducted in Mexico that compared 15 girls with TS to 15 healthy controls, researchers demonstrated that girls with TS had more difficulty in complex syntactic comprehension compared to healthy controls(10) -The researchers also concluded that the subjects with TS had more impulsivity when compared to typically developing peers(19) -In a research study conducted in the United Kingdom comparing 19 girls with TS to 20 healthy controls, researchers demonstrated a statistically significant difference in the oral fluency skills of girls with TS as compared to typically developing females(23) -Oral fluency was assessed over 3 trials by asking participants to say as many words as they could think of in 60 seconds that began with the letter “f,” then “a,” then “s”(23) -Total words generated by patients with TS was 23.00 vs 34.95 for healthy group(23) -Oral fluency can also be informally assessed by asking the patient to say as many animal names as he or she can think of in 60 secondsA connected speech sample is an appropriate assessment tool for patients with TS. Speech samples are obtained during an evaluation session by using a conversational or play format. Researchers have used wordless picture books to assist patients in generating connected speech. It is best to video or audiotape the sample so that it may be analyzed at a later time(23)can be used as a gross measure of syntactic development(23) -An utterance is a unit of speech surrounded by silence; may also use intonation contours as a guide to determine what constitutes an utterance -Ratio for MLU is calculated by dividing total number of words by the number of utterancesTo be determined by the evaluating SLP; tests utilized in research with TS patients include(23) standardized test of confrontation-naming ability(23) normed for persons aged 2½–90 years old; standardized test for receptive vocabulary -V ocabulary skills appear to be a strength for girls with TS(22)Briefly assess vocal function, including vocal quality, loudness, pitch, and endurance; if there are specific concerns regarding voice, refer to an otolaryngologist for a complete workup to rule out laryngeal pathologies before completing a full evaluation -Girls with TS might experience voice changes as a result of hormone therapy(15)Patients with TS sometimes have fluency disturbances.(9,15)For detailed information on disorders of fluency, see the series of the Clinical Reviews on this topicWhen developmentally appropriate, include a brief assessment of reading ability in the evaluation. In the school setting, the special education teacher or reading specialist will most like be responsible for the direct teaching of reading and writing skills. However, the SLP might play a support role in assessing and treating the child for reading difficulties
relevant tests and measures.oral structure and oral motor function: An oral mechanism examination should be completed with all TS patients.(15,24)Is the face symmetrical at rest? Is the face symmetrical while making movements (smiling, raising the eyebrows, closing the eyes)? Are there any abnormal movements (twitching, spasms, grimacing)? Is the patient drooling or mouth breathing?Are the lips symmetrical at rest? Are the lips symmetrical during movements? Is ROM normal? Is the strength normal? Is the lip tissue healthy? Is there any scarring or cleft?Is the tongue normal in appearance? Any atrophy? Any discolorations? Any bleeding? Is the range of motion normal? Is the strength normal?Is the hard palate intact? Any signs of fistulas, fissures, scarring? Are the height and width normal? Any prostheses present? Is the coloration normal? -Girls with TS often present with a high-arched palate(5) –Soft palate -Is the coloration normal (should be pink and white)?  -Any signs of cleft or bifid uvula? Does the patient sound hyper-  or hyponasal during conversational speech? -Place a small mirror under the patient’s nose during production of nonnasal sounds; if fogging or clouding occur this might indicate nasal emission, which would indicate the need for a referral to the otolaryngologistAre there any missing teeth? Are the teeth in good repair? Does the patient wear braces or retainers? Is there a significant overbite or underbite? Common differences related to the teeth in patients with TS include micrognathia (abnormally small jaw) and retrognathic maxilla and mandible (abnormal posterior positioning of the facial and jaw bones)(1,4,33)
relevant tests and measures.arousal attention cognition: Patients with TS often present with impaired executive functioning, resulting in impaired attention, concentration, problem-solving  skills, organization, visuospatial working memory, and impulsivity(4,6,19,20,21,22) –Some studies suggest that, in girls with TS, cognitive impairments are exacerbated by estrogen deficiency(6) –Refer to neuropsychological testing for more information regarding patient-specific  cognitive-linguistic  strengths and weaknesses
relevant tests and measures.swallow examination: Assess swallowing as indicated –Infants with TS might present with suck/swallow deficits and feeding or swallowing problems.(4) If the caregiver reports symptoms of dysphagia, a bedside (or “chairside”) swallowing evaluation may be performed by the SLP initially; however, may require a modified barium swallow study as per the therapist’s discretion. Infant feeding and disorders of infant and child swallowing are specialized areas of speech pathology. Referral should be made to an SLP, outpatient clinic, or hospital that specializes in infant feeding problems. (For additional information on assessment and treatment of dysphagia, see the series of Clinical Reviews on this topic)

other: Only those contraindications/precautions applicable to this diagnosis are mentioned below. Rehabilitation professionals should always use their professional judgment

Patients with TS may be at risk for falls due to impaired gait; follow facility protocols for fall prevention and post fall prevention instructions at bedside, if inpatient. Ensure that patient and family/caregivers are aware of the potential for falls and educated about fall prevention strategies. Discharge criteria should include independence with fall prevention strategies

Patients with this diagnosis might be at risk for dysphagia; follow recommended protocols for swallowing safety and post feeding instructions at the bedside, if inpatient. Ensure that the patient and family/caregivers are aware of the potential for dysphagia and educated about safe feeding strategies

Clinicians should follow the guidelines of their clinic/hospital and what is ordered by the patient’s physician. The summary below is meant to serve as a guide, not to replace orders from a physician or a clinic’s specific protocols

assessment plan of care.diagnosis need for treatment: Speech therapy for patients with TS can focus on speech, language, and/or cognitive-linguistic  and/or feeding/swallowing deficits as determined following a thorough evaluation by a licensed and certified SLP. Speech therapy should be one aspect of a multidisciplinary approach to treating an individual with TS Per Clinical Guidelines developed at the 2016 Cincinnati International Turner Syndrome Meeting and endorsed by the American Academy of Pediatrics, children with TS should be referred for physical, occupational, and speech therapy as early as possible and upon the start of formal education if developmental delays are observed due to the increased risk for motor and communication impairment(36,37)
assessment plan of care.rule out: To provide the best possible treatment, the patient’s medical team will attempt to rule out the following diagnoses before making a diagnosis of TS: GH deficiency(1) Klippel-Feil  anomaly(1) Léri-Weill  syndrome(1) Multiple pterygium syndrome(1) Noonan syndrome(1) Polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS)(1) Pseudo hypoparathyroid syndrome(1)
prognosis: One to two percent of women will spontaneously conceive(1,4) –In vitro fertilization and other infertility treatments might be available to allow women with TS to reproduce(1)
assessment plan of care.referral to other disciplines: The following referrals might be appropriate for patients with TS Refer to physical and occupational therapy if the patient has reduced mobility or difficulty with ADLs  Refer to a neurologist if the patient has not already undergone neurological and/or neuropsychological examination Refer to an ophthalmologist if vision problems are noted or reported by the patient during the examination(3) Refer to an audiologistand/or otolaryngologist if the patient fails hearing screening and/or appears to have difficulty hearing during the evaluation(11) –Girls with TS are at an increased risk of both conductive and sensorineural hearing loss when compared to the general population(13) Refer to learning disabilities specialist if parents of a child with TS report difficulty in school subjects(1) Due to the unique challenges of caring for a daughter with TS, parents sometimes have difficulty coping with stress resulting in depression and/or anxiety –Referral to a psychiatrist, psychologist, or family counseling might be appropriate if patient and/or the patient’s parents describe difficulty coping with stress, hopeless thoughts, and/or depression(6)

improved articulation increased speech i: Formal and informal measures of articulation
improved receptive and expressive langua: Formal and informal measures of language abilities

maintenance or prevention: There is no way to prevent TS
Early diagnosis and medical/hormonal intervention improves functional outcomes for girls with TS(3,4)
Patients with TS should have cardiac evaluations every 3 to 4 years because of the increased risk of cardiovascular abnormalities(5)
patient education: Information, education, research, and other resources available online at the Turner Syndrome Society of the United States, https://www.turnersyndrome.org/

The Magic Foundation, a support group for families of children with GH deficiencies, (Major Aspects of Growth In Children [MAGIC]), https://www.magicfoundation.org/ Coding Matrix References are rated using the following codes, listed in order of strength: MPublished meta-analysis SRPublished systematic or integrative literature review RCTPublished research (randomized controlled trial) RPublished research (not randomized controlled trial) CCase histories, case studies GPublished guidelinesRVPublished review of the literature RUPublished research utilization report QIPublished quality improvement report LLegislation PGRPublished government report PFRPublished funded reportPPPolicies, procedures, protocols XPractice exemplars, stories, opinions GIGeneral or background information/texts/reports UUnpublished research, reviews, poster presentations or other such materials CPConference proceedings, abstracts, presentation
